examples.en: I entered the hot springs and felt a blissful feeling.
examples.ja: 温泉に入って極楽気分を味わいました。

examples.en: If you do bad things, you can't go to paradise.
examples.ja: 悪いことをしてたら、極楽に行けないよ。

examples.en: The novel about a man who went to paradise by mistake was made into a movie.
examples.ja: 間違いで極楽に行った男についての小説が、映画化されました。

examples.en: Gokuraku Tombo (dragonfly in paradise) is a term used to mockingly describe people who are unaware of the seriousness of a situation and take it lightly. However nowadays, most people only know it as the comedy duo's name.
examples.ja: 「極楽とんぼ」とは、事の重大さに気づかず、のんきに構えている人のことをあざけて言う言葉です。でも、今では芸人さんのコンビ名としてしか知らない人がほとんどですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This place has <kanji>extreme</kanji> <kanji>comfort</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>paradise</vocabulary>.

極楽 is a short for 極楽浄土 (the Pure Land in Mahayana Buddhism). While it might sound a bit old-fashioned, you can still use it to describe something heavenly. For example, if you're soaking in a cozy, relaxing hot spring, you could say, "Ahhh…極楽!"
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 極 has two on'yomi readings, though. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

In <vocabulary>paradise</vocabulary>, you meet <reading>Goku</reading> (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z. He grins and tells you he's taking a break from extreme battles and enjoying the extreme comfort of this heavenly paradise.

examples.en: I broke my butt bone slipping in the bathroom.
examples.ja: 風呂場で滑ってお尻の骨を折りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the <kanji>place</kanji> you take a bath in is the <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary>!

Note that this word means "bathroom" in the literal sense — it's not a word for "restroom."
reading_mnemonic:
This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 場. You didn't learn the kun'yomi reading for 場 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

You step into the <vocabulary>bathroom</vocabulary> and hear an angry chorus of <reading>baa</reading>s (ば). You're mortified to find that you've accidentally entered the side of the public bath reserved exclusively for sheep. You rush back out, bowing and baaing apologies.

examples.en: This is my first time going to a public bathhouse.
examples.ja: 風呂屋に来るのは初めてです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the <kanji>store</kanji> you pay to take a bath in is the <vocabulary>public bathhouse</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

examples.en: I’m taking a course on medical ethics.
examples.ja: 医学倫理学の講座を受けています。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 倫理 means "ethics" so when you add <kanji>study</kanji> it means the <vocabulary>ethics</vocabulary> you study in school.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our company was selected as one of the most ethical in the world.
examples.ja: うちの会社は、世界で最も倫理的な企業の一つに選ばれました。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>ethic</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji> are <vocabulary>ethical</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Your way of thinking is really biased, isn't it?
examples.ja: あなたって、考え方にすごく偏りがあるよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 偏る, so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: Only the king can wear this crown.
examples.ja: この冠を被れるのは王だけです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, and that is its most common reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

In your mind, the only person who can wear a <vocabulary>crown</vocabulary> is Bill Murray. He asks you, "Can I wear the crown?" and you say "Yes you <reading>can, Murray</reading> (かんむり)". Murray goes ahead and puts on the crown. He's movie royalty, after all.

examples.en: He was in love and abandoned the crown.
examples.ja: 彼は恋をして王冠を捨てたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>king</kanji>'s <kanji>cap</kanji> is his <vocabulary>crown</vocabulary>. It's a hat only he can wear.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Both offense and defense played with distinction.
examples.ja: 攻守ともに殊勲を立てました。

meaning_mnemonic: You do things <kanji>especially</kanji> worthy of <kanji>merit</kanji> and they're called <vocabulary>meritorious deeds</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Every year, in spring and fall, the spring and fall conferring of decorations is carried out.
examples.ja: 毎年、春と秋に春秋叙勲が実施されます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Describe</kanji> someone's <kanji>merit</kanji> at a ceremony for the <vocabulary>conferring of decorations</vocabulary>. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did you decline the winning medal?
examples.ja: どうして勲章の受賞を辞退したんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: To show that you had <kanji>merit</kanji> for a <kanji>chapter</kanji> of your life you will be given a <vocabulary>decoration</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>medal</vocabulary>. Especially if you're a soldier or an athlete.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We sell wholesale goods.
examples.ja: うちは雑貨の卸をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Will you sell these goods wholesale?
examples.ja: うちにもその商品を卸してもらえませんか。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wholesale</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sell wholesale</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: I was able to buy it at wholesale price.
examples.ja: それは卸値で購入することができたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you sell something at <kanji>wholesale</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji> it's being sold at a <vocabulary>wholesale price</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I went to observe the wholesale market.
examples.ja: 卸売市場の見学をしてきました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sell</kanji> something at the <kanji>wholesale</kanji> price and it's... well it's <vocabulary>wholesale</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes it's spelled 卸売り too.

examples.en: "The Epic of Gilgamesh" is a literary work from ancient Mesopotamia.
examples.ja: 『ギルガメシュ叙事詩』は、古代メソポタミアの文学作品です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>describe</kanji> a bunch of <kanji>occurrence</kanji>s in a <kanji>poem</kanji>, it's probably an <vocabulary>epic poem</vocabulary>. This is for those super long, really descriptive poems you might be forced to read in school, like The Epic of Gilgamesh (ギルガメシュ叙事詩).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In this lesson we’re going to learn to link together illustrations, photographs, and descriptions.
examples.ja: この授業では、挿し絵や写真と叙述を結び付けることを学びます。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>describe</kanji> an event by <kanji>mention</kanji>ing everything that happened, you must be <vocabulary>giving an account</vocabulary> of it.

叙述 refers to <vocabulary>narrating</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>describing</vocabulary> events in an orderly sequence. It usually suggests a specific writing technique associated with storytelling and narrative.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m studying to be able to cleverly describe my feelings.
examples.ja: うまく叙情できるよう勉強しています。

meaning_mnemonic: The best way to <kanji>describe</kanji> your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s is with <vocabulary>lyricism</vocabulary>. Making a clear <vocabulary>description of feelings</vocabulary> is difficult, but it will make you feel better.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m thinking of selling my autobiography as an e-book.
examples.ja: 電子書籍で自叙伝を販売しようと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Tell</kanji> everyone how you <kanji>describe</kanji> your<kanji>self</kanji> in your <vocabulary>autobiography</vocabulary>. It's the only way they'll be able to understand the real you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I was a student I only did stupid things.
examples.ja: 学生の頃は、いつも阿呆なことばかりしてたな。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Shock</kanji> someone by <kanji>flatter</kanji>ing them and they'll end up looking like a <vocabulary>fool</vocabulary>. Taking compliments always turns people into silly <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary>s. It's okay, they're just embarrassed.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own, but keep in mind that the reading is often shortened to あほ these days.

examples.en: That actor is really good at acting senile.
examples.ja: あの芸人は呆けるのが本当にうまい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shock</kanji>. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start <vocabulary>to grow senile</vocabulary>. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you start <vocabulary>to grow senile</vocabulary> you'll make a new friend. It's <reading>Bo</reading>bo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

examples.en: Their cheating was completely exposed.
examples.ja: あいつがしていたインチキが全部露呈したんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Present</kanji> and <kanji>expose</kanji> wrongdoing to get proper <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>. The world needs <vocabulary>disclosure</vocabulary> and so do you!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: T-points are presented to those blogs with a lot of visitors.
examples.ja: 訪問者の多いブログには、Tポイントが進呈されます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Present</kanji> your findings in <kanji>advance</kanji> during an early <vocabulary>presentation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I presented flowers to a friend who was playing the leading role.
examples.ja: 主役を演じた友人に花束を贈呈しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Present</kanji> your <kanji>presents</kanji> at the <vocabulary>presentation</vocabulary>. Presents for everyone!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The method of nursing infants is changing greatly.
examples.ja: 乳児哺育の方法は大きく変化しています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Nurse</kanji> and <kanji>raise</kanji> your baby by <vocabulary>nursing</vocabulary>. Milk helps babies grow up big and strong.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The anger that had built up burst out at once.
examples.ja: 今までためていた怒りが一気に噴き出した。

meaning_mnemonic: "To Remove" an <kanji>eruption</kanji> it needs <vocabulary>to burst out</vocabulary> of the earth or volcano it's in.
reading_mnemonic: Remember how you learned the word 吹き出す? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!

examples.en: I spent my childhood in an orphanage.
examples.ja: 私は孤児院で幼少期を過ごしました。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that the word 孤児 means "orphan," so when you put a bunch of orphans in an <kanji>institution</kanji> it's called an <vocabulary>orphanage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If I warm it up and eat it, it becomes even more delicious.
examples.ja: 温めて食べたら、尚、おいしくなりますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When is the best time to use the word <vocabulary>furthermore</vocabulary>? Right <reading>now</reading> (なお)! That's because you've just finished saying what you originally wanted to say, and now, you've realized there's even more you want to say.

examples.en: Once upon a time there was a high priest who loved starch syrup.
examples.ja: 昔々あるところに、水飴が大好きな和尚がおりました。

meaning_mnemonic: Who works for <kanji>peace</kanji> and is held in high <kanji>esteem</kanji>? A <vocabulary>Buddhist high priest</vocabulary>. They work harder than anyone else to reach world peace so they're held in very high esteem.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The only thing you ever hear the <vocabulary>Buddhist High Priest</vocabulary> say is "<reading>O</reading>ooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.

examples.en: You have such refined tastes.
examples.ja: 高尚な趣味をお持ちなんですね。

meaning_mnemonic: You only hold someone in <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>esteem</kanji> if they are really <vocabulary>high</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>noble</vocabulary> people. They have to be <vocabulary>refined</vocabulary> to be held so highly by you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I think it’s premature to broach that topic.
examples.ja: その話を持ち出すのは時期尚早だろう。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that the word 時期 means "time period," so when you add <kanji>furthermore</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> to that, it means that something happened ahead of time. It means <vocabulary>premature</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The story has nothing to do with a common person like me.
examples.ja: 私みたいな庶民には関係のない話です。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Common</kanji> <kanji>peoples</kanji> make up the <vocabulary>masses</vocabulary>. They are the <vocabulary>common people</vocabulary> and no society is complete without them.

Depending on the context, 庶民 can take on a slightly negative connotation, especially if the 庶民 in question are contrasted with more elite or sophisticated groups.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It will be assigned to the general affairs department this time.
examples.ja: こんど、庶務課に配属されることになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Common</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji>s are a part of the <vocabulary>general affairs</vocabulary> of the people. That's why they're general, they're the ones everyone is involved in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A person who works hard talks of hope but a person who is idle talks of dissatisfaction.
examples.ja: 努力する人は希望を語るが、怠ける人は不満を語るのさ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>neglect</kanji> and <kanji>lazy</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to neglect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be idle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You decide <vocabulary>to neglect</vocabulary> everything. Your school, your family, even your own <reading>name</reading> (なま). You've managed <vocabulary>to slack</vocabulary> for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

examples.en: After retirement I want to live a quiet life in the countryside.
examples.ja: 退職後は田舎で悠々と暮らしたいな。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Leisure</kanji> with more <kanji>leisure</kanji> added on? That's a really <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>leisurely</vocabulary> life you've got going on!

Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

examples.en: I thought about various things about human life within the eternity of mother nature.
examples.ja: 悠久な大自然で、人生について色々なことを考えてみました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Leisure</kanji> that last for a <kanji>long time</kanji> ends up going on for all <vocabulary>eternity</vocabulary>. It never ends, and why should it? You're soooo relaaaaaxed, you can't possibly ever stop.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This isn’t the time to talk about such leisurely things.
examples.ja: そんな悠長なことを言ってる時間はないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>leisure</kanji> makes everything you do <vocabulary>leisurely</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary>. You're able to perform tasks at a <vocabulary>deliberate</vocabulary> rate because nothing's rushing you. And you've been like this for so long, why would anything try?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am very sorry for the foolish things I said to you earlier.
examples.ja: 先ほどは愚なことを申し上げてしまいまして、誠に申し訳ございませんでした。

examples.en: I spent the evening with my best friend talking about silly things.
examples.ja: 親友と、愚にもつかない話をして夜を過ごした。

examples.en: This is certainly the height of folly.
examples.ja: まさに愚の骨頂だね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Since this word is both a noun and a na-adjective, it can also mean things like <vocabulary>folly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>foolishness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: If you only talk of idle complaints, nothing will change.
examples.ja: 愚痴ばかり言っても、何も変わらないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>foolish</kanji> and <kanji>stupid</kanji> person will make lots of <vocabulary>idle complaint</vocabulary>s. You really don't like being around them because they <vocabulary>grumble</vocabulary> about how nothing is good enough all the time. But they really just don't get it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is the first time I’ve met such an arrogant man.
examples.ja: あんな傲慢な男は初めてだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>ridicule</kanji> other people because you're so <kanji>proud</kanji> of yourself that everyone seems like crap in comparison, you've got too much <vocabulary>pride</vocabulary>. You should also work on toning down your <vocabulary>arrogance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>haughtiness</vocabulary>, because people won't like you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m going to kidnap the manager’s son.
examples.ja: 社長の息子を誘拐するつもりだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Invite</kanji> someone to <kanji>kidnap</kanji> you and you'll have a <vocabulary>kidnapping</vocabulary> on your hands. That wasn't very smart. You should try to be more careful.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I made dried apricot jam.
examples.ja: 干し杏のジャムを作りました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!

examples.en: Poisoning symptoms develop when I eat too much ginkgo.
examples.ja: 銀杏を食べ過ぎると中毒症状が出ます。

meaning_mnemonic: If it looks like a <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>apricot</kanji>, it's probably a <vocabulary>ginkgo</vocabulary>. Ever seen a <vocabulary>ginkgo nut</vocabulary> from a <vocabulary>ginkgo tree</vocabulary>? They really do look like little silver apricots. (Go ahead and google it if you don't believe me.)
reading_mnemonic:
This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now.

When you think of the <vocabulary>ginkgo tree</vocabulary> meaning, think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for <reading>ea</reading>gles (い), but evil Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) likes to eat eagles AND whole ginkgo trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And ginkgo trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo.

The other reading is for the <vocabulary>ginkgo nut</vocabulary> meaning. The nut tastes like <reading>銀</reading> (ぎん) <reading>naan</reading> (なん). Mmm, soft and metallic — but still not a jukugo word. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

examples.en: When you read books do you use a bookmark?
examples.ja: 本を読む時に栞は使いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I’m growing tomatoes in my garden.
examples.ja: 庭でトマトを栽培しているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Planting</kanji> seeds in land to <kanji>cultivate</kanji> crops is called <vocabulary>cultivation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you buy bonsai in America too?
examples.ja: アメリカでも盆栽が買えるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Tray</kanji> <kanji>planting</kanji> is <vocabulary>bonsai</vocabulary>. It makes sense because that's exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray!

盆栽 refers both to the art of cultivating these miniature trees in small trays (or pots), as well as to those bonsai trees themselves.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please leave this column blank.
examples.ja: この欄は空けておいてください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Please fill out your response in the blank space.
examples.ja: 空欄に答えを書き込んでください。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>space</kanji> as empty as the <kanji>sky</kanji> is a <vocabulary>blank space</vocabulary>. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This guardrail is old so you shouldn’t lean on it.
examples.ja: その欄干は古いからもたれないほうがいい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>column</kanji> made of <kanji>dry</kanji> wood is turned into a <vocabulary>guardrail</vocabulary> to help people walk up and down stairs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I wonder if it’s okay that my signature is going out of the margins.
examples.ja: サインが欄外にはみ出てしまったんですが、大丈夫でしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you write <kanji>outside</kanji> the <kanji>column</kanji>s in your notebook paper you're actually writing in the <vocabulary>margin</vocabulary>s. It's a good space to put doodles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Additionally, next year will be the memorial year commemorating the one hundredth year anniversary of Koichi-sama’s birth.
examples.ja: 殊に、来年はコウイチ様生誕100周年を記念するメモリアル・イヤーとなります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This is the kanji followed by the particle に, so it uses the kun'yomi reading like a kanji does if it's alone. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What do you wear when it's <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> cold out? Your favorite <reading>coat</reading> (こと). You only wear it when it's <vocabulary>unusually</vocabulary> cold though, never any other time.

examples.en: Many victims appeared from the airplane accident.
examples.ja: その飛行機事故では、事故で多くの犠牲者がでました。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 犠牲 means "victim," so when you add <kanji>someone</kanji> to that, it still means <vocabulary>victim</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You disinfect the baby bottle in boiling water.
examples.ja: 哺乳瓶を熱湯消毒しています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>milk</kanji> <kanji>bottle</kanji> that babies use to <kanji>nurse</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>baby bottle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are a lot of areas troubled with depopulation in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本には、過疎に悩む地域がたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: If the <kanji>neglect</kanji> of an area <kanji>surpass</kanji>es what was expected, then the result will be <vocabulary>depopulation</vocabulary>. No one wants to live in a neglected town, especially one that's worse than what they were told.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Continuing such a futile dispute is a waste of time.
examples.ja: こんな空疎な論争を続けるのは時間の無駄だ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sky</kanji> has an air of <kanji>neglect</kanji> about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in <vocabulary>vain</vocabulary>. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: With that, I became estranged from my older sister.
examples.ja: それっきり、姉とは疎遠になっているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If your <kanji>neglect</kanji> of family members goes too <kanji>far</kanji> you'll end up with <vocabulary>estrangement</vocabulary> in your relationships with them. And they'll probably <vocabulary>neglect</vocabulary> you as much as you neglect them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They were evacuated to the countryside to avoid the air raids.
examples.ja: 空襲を避けるために田舎へ疎開していました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You’re looking for a <kanji>neglect</kanji>ed place that you can <kanji>open</kanji> up and use for <vocabulary>evacuation</vocabulary>.

While 避難 is a more general term for evacuating or seeking shelter during emergencies, 疎開 describes evacuating specifically from cities or crowded areas to safer places during disasters like earthquakes, tsunamis, etc.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I had constantly felt alienated in school.
examples.ja: 学校ではずっと疎外感を感じていました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Neglect</kanji> someone so much that you remove yourself from their inner circle and live <kanji>outside</kanji> of their life and it's called <vocabulary>estrangement</vocabulary>. You might never see them again. But that's okay with you, your relationship is too weird to fix now.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There is no way I can come to a mutual understanding with him.
examples.ja: 彼とは、意思疎通が全然できないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you never <kanji>neglect</kanji> to <kanji>pass through</kanji> your thoughts to another person the two of you will be able to have a special <vocabulary>mutual understanding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s bustling during the day, but at night pedestrian traffic is sparse.
examples.ja: 昼間は賑やかですが、夜になると人通りも疎らになります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When things are <vocabulary>sparse</vocabulary>, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your <reading>ma</reading>ma would <reading>baa</reading> (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

examples.en: My little sister has a mental disorder.
examples.ja: 私の妹は、精神疾患を抱えています。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that you are <kanji>afflicted</kanji> with <kanji>rapid</kanji>ly is a <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary>. You should go to the doctor's right away to treat this fast-acting ailment.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The boys sprinted around the station.
examples.ja: 少年は、駅の構内を全力疾走していた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rapid</kanji> <kanji>run</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>sprint</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>dash</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The black dog ran through the river bed like a gust of wind.
examples.ja: 真っ黒な犬が、疾風のように河原を駆け抜けていった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rapid</kanji> <kanji>wind</kanji> is a <vocabulary>gale</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>strong wind</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The three major diseases are cancer, heart attack, and stroke.
examples.ja: がん、急性心筋梗塞、脳卒中のことを三大疾病といいます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rapid</kanji> <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is an <vocabulary>illness</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings, but you haven't seen the へい reading for 病 yet. In fact, this is pretty much the only word it appears in, and on top of that it gets rendaku'd. So here's a mnemonic to help you out:

If you don't treat an <vocabulary>illness</vocabulary> right away, you might <reading>pay</reading> (ぺい) with your life. And if you don't die, you'll still have to pay a lot for doctor and hospital fees. Yuck.

examples.en: I’m tone-deaf so I’m bad at karaoke.
examples.ja: 音痴なので、カラオケは苦手です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>stupid</kanji> when it comes to <kanji>sound</kanji>s, then you're <vocabulary>tone deaf</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My grandmother is starting to get dementia.
examples.ja: 祖母の痴呆が始まったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you seem <kanji>stupid</kanji> and <kanji>shock</kanji>ed all the time you might have <vocabulary>dementia</vocabulary>. It makes it so everything is unfamiliar and confusing, so you can't help looking silly and confused all the time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The molester was arrested this morning.
examples.ja: 今朝、痴漢を逮捕しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>stupid</kanji> <kanji>man</kanji> is a <vocabulary>groper</vocabulary>. I mean, not always. But it's probably fair to call a groper or <vocabulary>molester</vocabulary> a stupid man.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Thousands of bottles of nail polish are disorderly lined up in the closet.
examples.ja: 戸棚の中には、何千本というマニキュアが無秩序に並べられていた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 秩序 means "order?" Well if you have <kanji>nothing</kanji> like that then it falls into <vocabulary>disorder</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>chaos</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: With the staff scandal coming to light, all employees are to restrain themselves from doing business activities today.
examples.ja: 役員の不祥事発覚を受け、本日は全社員が営業活動を自粛致します。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>solemn</kanji> by your<kanji>self</kanji>, you have a lot of <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary>. You don't need anyone to tell you to be that way, you have your own <vocabulary>self discipline</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I want to solemnly react to the results and face it next time.
examples.ja: 結果を厳粛に受け止め、次回に臨みたい。

meaning_mnemonic: If everyone is acting <kanji>solemn</kanji> and <kanji>strict</kanji> then you should probably pay special attention to the <vocabulary>gravity</vocabulary> of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please be silent.
examples.ja: 静粛に願います。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>solemn</kanji> <kanji>quiet</kanji> person will always be <vocabulary>silent</vocabulary>. They never ever speak.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They plan to use starvation tactics.
examples.ja: 兵糧攻めをするつもりなんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Provisions</kanji> that are only for <kanji>soldier</kanji>s are <vocabulary>army provisions</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the reading for the second kanji but not the first one yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

The army said it would provide you with some <vocabulary>army provisions</vocabulary>. That's great! You go to the drop site where the provisions are, and you see the provisions. "<reading>Heyo!</reading> It's <reading>roe</reading>!" (ひょうろう) you say out loud. You're pretty happy that your provisions consist of tons and tons of roe!

examples.en: Is there a picture of the groom wearing the crested hakama?
examples.ja: 新郎が紋付袴を着ている写真はありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: The fingerprints on the doorknob were completely wiped off.
examples.ja: ドアノブの指紋を綺麗に拭き取った。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>family crest</kanji> on your <kanji>finger</kanji>? That's just your <vocabulary>fingerprint</vocabulary>. It can be used to identify you, so it's pretty much the same as your own personal family crest.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The cabinet minister’s careless remark created a huge stir.
examples.ja: 大臣の不用意な発言が波紋を呼んだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Throw your <kanji>family crest</kanji> into the <kanji>wave</kanji>s and you'll make lots of <vocabulary>ripple</vocabulary>s. There will probably also be <vocabulary>repercussions</vocabulary> with your family because those things are important and you really shouldn't be tossing them into the sea's waves.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is the royal family’s crest.
examples.ja: これは、王家の紋章です。

meaning_mnemonic: Look at a <kanji>chapter</kanji> on <kanji>family crest</kanji>s in that book and you'll see every <vocabulary>crest</vocabulary> in your area.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My hopes just got bigger.
examples.ja: 希望は膨らむばかりだった。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>swell</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to swell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "<reading>F@#$</reading> (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

examples.en: Can you eat rose stems?
examples.ja: 薔薇の茎を食べることはできますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: My parents’ home is in Ibaraki prefecture.
examples.ja: 茨城県に実家があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>prefecture</kanji> famous for its ancient <kanji>thorn</kanji> <kanji>castle</kanji> is <vocabulary>Ibaraki prefecture</vocabulary>. I may or may not be making this up. Don't fact check me, just look at that cool thorny castle in Ibaraki that I put in your head. Ooooh, how cool!
reading_mnemonic:
This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 茨, an exception for 城, and the on'yomi for 県. Phew! You haven't learned this weird reading for 城 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Ibaraki prefecture</vocabulary> is famous for making <reading>key</reading>s (き)! It's their biggest export. The key to knowing this reading is in the keys they make! Or, just knowing that it's the same in English and Japanese.

examples.en: A tragedy occurred at a particular closed mountain retreat.
examples.ja: ある閉ざされた山荘で悲劇は起きた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>villa</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mountain retreat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The ceremony was held solemnly.
examples.ja: その儀式は荘厳に行われました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>villa</kanji> that's kept under really <kanji>strict</kanji> rules will press <vocabulary>solemnity</vocabulary> on everyone who tries to stay there.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 厳 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

To help you understand the <vocabulary>solemnity</vocabulary> of a moment of silence, usually a <reading>gon</reading>g (ごん) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.

examples.en: I plan on selling the villa in spring.
examples.ja: この春に別荘を売ってしまうつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>villa</kanji> <kanji>separate</kanji> from your normal house is a <vocabulary>holiday house</vocabulary>. You go there when you're sick of your normal house to relax.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Let’s tie up today’s karaoke with a Noh song from the Showa era.
examples.ja: 今日のカラオケは、昭和歌謡縛りにしよう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> out a <kanji>song</kanji> makes it an even longer, more confusing <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>. But it's still a song nonetheless!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve learned new nursery rhymes in kindergarten.
examples.ja: 幼稚園で新しい童謡を習ってきました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> for <kanji>juvenile</kanji>s are <vocabulary>nursery rhyme</vocabulary>s. Kids won't understand the heavy stuff, so you have to dumb it down for them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Lately, I’ve been listening to Russian folk songs everyday.
examples.ja: 最近は毎日ロシア民謡を聞いています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>peoples</kanji> <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> is <vocabulary>folk songs</vocabulary>. They're the songs for the common people.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He stuck to his beliefs until the end.
examples.ja: 彼は最後まで自分の信念を貫き通しました。

examples.en: Sticking to your own style is not as easy as you think.
examples.ja: 自分のスタイルを貫き通すのは、思ってるほど簡単じゃないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a combination of the words 貫く (to go through) and 通す (to let pass). Literally, it can describe piercing fully through an object. However, 貫き通す is usually used figuratively to mean <vocabulary>to stick to</vocabulary> something to the very end. Just like piercing an object from one side to the other, 貫き通す implies you push forward no matter what, sticking to your beliefs or determinations all the way.
reading_mnemonic: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!

examples.en: You may be expected to pay reparations.
examples.ja: 賠償金をお支払い頂く可能性があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Gold</kanji> you get as <kanji>compensation</kanji> for <kanji>reparation</kanji>s is called <vocabulary>reparations</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Theories are meaningful only if put into practice.
examples.ja: 理論は実践に移してこそ意味があるのです。

meaning_mnemonic: To tell you the <kanji>truth</kanji>, <kanji>practice</kanji> is <vocabulary>practice</vocabulary>. You can't just substitute something else for it. You'll only make progress with real practice! You can do it!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This school has an interesting anecdote.
examples.ja: この学校には面白い逸話があってね。

meaning_mnemonic: How do you <kanji>deviate</kanji> from a normal <kanji>talk</kanji>? With lots of <vocabulary>anecdote</vocabulary>s. If you add enough of them into your conversations no one will ever be able to keep track of what you were talking about to begin with.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This Japanese Black steak is a gem chefs obsess over.
examples.ja: この黒毛和牛のステーキは、シェフのこだわりの逸品です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Deviate</kanji> from normal, everyday <kanji>product</kanji>s and buy lots of <vocabulary>gem</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>treasure</vocabulary>s! Especially if you're buying presents. Normal stuff just isn't going to cut it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please refrain from tasks that deviate from the mission.
examples.ja: 任務を逸脱する行為は慎み給え。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>deviate</kanji> from the plan and <kanji>escape</kanji> from it, that's a serious <vocabulary>deviation</vocabulary> and could ruin everything! Stick to the plan! Stop deviating!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Rumor has it, this advertisement is really excellent.
examples.ja: この広告は非常に秀逸だと評判です。

meaning_mnemonic: Do you <kanji>excel</kanji> when you <kanji>deviate</kanji> from the norm? Well, then you're made for <vocabulary>excellence</vocabulary>, my friend!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: She quickly averted her eyes.
examples.ja: 彼女は颯と目を逸らした。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deviate</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to turn away</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to avert</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want <vocabulary>to turn away</vocabulary> from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just <reading>so</reading>-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

examples.en: This bookstore always displays books by my favorite author in the most preferential way.
examples.ja: この本屋はいつも私の好きな作家の本を最優遇して陳列してくれているんです。

examples.en: In terms of policy, all the political parties in Japan give the highest priority to the elderly, don't they?
examples.ja: 政策的には、日本のどの政党も高齢者を最優遇していますよね。

examples.en: This store prioritizes cash-paying members, allowing them to proceed to the checkout before card-paying members or non-members.
examples.ja: このお店は現金払いの会員が最優遇されていて、カード払いの会員や非会員よりも先にレジに進むことができます。

examples.en: How much is the prime lending rate right now?
examples.ja: 最優遇貸出金利はいまどのぐらいですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>treatment</kanji> is another way of saying it's the <vocabulary>most favorable treatment</vocabulary> you've ever received. It's when you get the <vocabulary>warmest reception</vocabulary> out of everyone around you. Like they think you're the president or something. Either way, it's pretty great!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Both teams’ fans continued to exchange jeers.
examples.ja: 両チームのファンからやじの応酬が続いた。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Repay</kanji> what someone lent you in <kanji>response</kanji> to them already lending YOU money, and the two of you will have <vocabulary>exchange</vocabulary>d money.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If this project is a success, Kristen will give me a kiss on the cheek as a reward.
examples.ja: このプロジェクトが成功すれば、報酬として、クリステンがほっぺにキスをしてくれます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Repay</kanji> people for the <kanji>news</kanji> they tell you by <vocabulary>reward</vocabulary>ing them! Everyone deserves <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary> for the time they take to pass information to you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Asking that guy for it is a bit too harsh.
examples.ja: それをあいつに頼むのは、ちょっと酷すぎやしないか。

examples.en: Everyone was saying it was a severe way to practice.
examples.ja: あれは、みんな酷な実践方法だったと言っていた。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>cruel</kanji> tends to be <vocabulary>harsh</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>severe</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary>. And of course, it's still <vocabulary>cruel</vocabulary> to boot.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: They’re being forced into unreasonably severe manual labor.
examples.ja: 彼らは、不当に過酷な労働を強いられています。

meaning_mnemonic: Your boss <kanji>surpass</kanji>es his normal <kanji>cruel</kanji>ty and rains <vocabulary>severity</vocabulary> down on your head. You had other things to do this weekend and now you have to work through it? <vocabulary>Harsh</vocabulary>...
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you think it’s okay to let black companies that exploit their workers continue to take care of themselves?
examples.ja: 労働者を酷使するブラック企業をこのまま野放しにしていてもいいんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>use</kanji> something in a <kanji>cruel</kanji> way it's called <vocabulary>exploitation</vocabulary>. You're probably going to <vocabulary>overuse</vocabulary> it, at that rate too. Cut it out, dude.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: All the content in the three volumes of the book resemble each other.
examples.ja: 三冊の本は、どれも内容が酷似している。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>resemble</kanji> someone who's <kanji>cruel</kanji>, you, well, you <vocabulary>resemble</vocabulary> them. Maybe you're really mean too. I guess only you can know that. But you do look like that other guy...
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 似 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Which cruel guy do you <vocabulary>resemble</vocabulary>? <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.

examples.en: All of the food she made tasted awful.
examples.ja: 彼女の作った料理は、どれも酷い味だった。

examples.en: How can you say such a cruel thing to your own girlfriend?
examples.ja: 自分の彼女によくもそんな酷い事が言えるね。

examples.en: If I had known the heat would be this severe, I wouldn't have moved to this country.
examples.ja: こんなに暑さが酷くなるって分かっていたら、この国に引っ越していなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cruel</kanji>? <vocabulary>Cruel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>awful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Think of a man who is <vocabulary>cruel</vocabulary>. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? <reading>He do</reading> (ひど) cruel things.

examples.en: This summer the intense heat continued.
examples.ja: 今年の夏は、酷暑が続きました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Cruel</kanji> <kanji>hot weather</kanji> is the kind that's too much for anyone to handle. It's <vocabulary>intense heat</vocabulary>. Stranded in the desert in summer, heat.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 暑 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Intense heat</vocabulary> will <reading>show</reading> (しょ) on your face. You'll turn red and get all sweaty. You really can't hide it.

examples.en: I was pressed for an awfully cruel decision.
examples.ja: 私は、ひどく残酷な決断を迫られました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of <kanji>cruel</kanji>ness is <vocabulary>cruelty</vocabulary>. There always seems to be plenty to go around, and it kind of sucks.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I always thought you were a cruel person.
examples.ja: あなたのこと、ずっと冷酷な人だと思っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cruel</kanji> <kanji>cool</kanji> person is more <vocabulary>cruel</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>coldhearted</vocabulary> than just a normal cruel person. It's probably because they're cold all the time and it makes them mad. You should stay away from people like that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can’t write anything if I pay an undue amount of attention to each severe criticism.
examples.ja: いちいち酷評を気にしてたら、何も書けないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Evaluate</kanji> in a <kanji>cruel</kanji> way so you can lay some <vocabulary>severe criticism</vocabulary> down on your competition! It's not the nicest thing to do, and it's not very constructive for them, but it will make you look better.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The sickle just slipped out of my hand.
examples.ja: 鎌をすっぽ抜けただけです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I’m going to introduce an exercise that improves my metabolism.
examples.ja: 新陳代謝がアップするエクササイズをご紹介します。

meaning_mnemonic: Your body thinks you want to <kanji>substitute</kanji> <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>exhibit</kanji>s inside yourself but it <kanji>apologize</kanji>s and replaces them more than you'd like. What it's actually doing is controlling your <vocabulary>metabolism</vocabulary>. Picture your body using food you eat by setting it up in an exhibit in your stomach. But it gets bored of it and wants to substitute it with a newer one, so it makes you hungry again, digesting the food fast.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know all of these, but 代 uses the less common たい reading, so here’s a mnemonic in case you’d like some help remembering that:

As everyone knows, the best way to boost your <vocabulary>metabolism</vocabulary> is to wear a <reading>tie</reading> (たい). They make your body more efficient overall, which includes your metabolism, so make sure you’re always wearing a tie for that metabolism boost!

examples.en: What the heck is on display in the showroom?
examples.ja: その陳列室には、いったい何が並べられているのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>exhibit</kanji> things in a <kanji>row</kanji> is a <vocabulary>showroom</vocabulary>. Maybe there are cars lined up, or boats, or tiny porcelain cats! Either way, they need a nice big showroom to show them off.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Shiny, toned skin is a must for popular women.
examples.ja: お肌の張りと艶は、モテる女の必須条件です。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 必須 can mean "essential" and that 条件 means "condition," so put them together and you get <vocabulary>essential condition</vocabulary>! That basically means that it's a <vocabulary>must</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How did you discover our plot?
examples.ja: どうして我々の陰謀が露顕したのだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>expose</kanji> something new and it <kanji>appear</kanji>s in front of the whole world as your <vocabulary>discovery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This picture symbolizes humanity’s conscious and subconscious.
examples.ja: この絵は、人間の顕在意識と潜在意識を象徴しています。

meaning_mnemonic: If it <kanji>appear</kanji>s to <kanji>exist</kanji>, then it's probably an <vocabulary>actual</vocabulary> thing... you know, existing and stuff. That should be pretty <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our company’s results are making a remarkable recovery.
examples.ja: 我が社の業績は顕著に回復しています。

meaning_mnemonic: When an <kanji>author</kanji> <kanji>appear</kanji>s in public it's always <vocabulary>remarkable</vocabulary>. People usually don't remember there's anyone behind those pages, so when the actual author shows up in person it's pretty <vocabulary>striking</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The commendation ceremony will be held at the civic center tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日、市民会館で顕彰式が行われます。

examples.en: I think we should create a system to honor community volunteer activities.
examples.ja: 私は、地域ボランティア活動を顕彰する制度を作るべきだと思うんです。

examples.en: I received a commendation the other day in appreciation of my 50 blood donations.
examples.ja: 先日、献血50回をねぎらう顕彰をいただきました。

examples.en: "The Prime Minister's Commendation" refers to an honor granted by the Prime Minister of Japan in recognition of  individuals or organizations that have made particularly outstanding achievements.
examples.ja: 「内閣総理大臣顕彰」とは、日本の内閣総理大臣が、特に功績のあった個人・団体をたたえるために授与する顕彰のことです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you want someone's awesomeness to <kanji>appear</kanji> <kanji>clear</kanji>ly to the world, you can start by <vocabulary>honoring</vocabulary> them. <vocabulary>Commending</vocabulary> someone in a public setting is a surefire way to let everyone know how great they are.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I ate whale bacon.
examples.ja: 鯨のベーコンを食べました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

A <vocabulary>whale</vocabulary> is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin <reading>kujira</reading> (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!

examples.en: I’m against whaling.
examples.ja: 私は捕鯨には反対です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>catch</kanji> a <kanji>whale</kanji> you're <vocabulary>whaling</vocabulary>, and that's illegal now so you should probably put the whale back.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I know a delicious whale meat shop.
examples.ja: 美味しい鯨肉の店を知っているよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Whale</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> is <vocabulary>whale meat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The sky was crimson in the sunset, and it was very beautiful.
examples.ja: 空が夕焼けで茜色に染まっていて、とても綺麗でした。

examples.en: We drank champagne while looking at the madder red sky.
examples.ja: 茜色の空を見ながら、シャンパンを飲んだ。

examples.en: Look, the sky is turning a fiery dark red color!
examples.ja: 見て、空が燃えるような茜色になってきてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Rose madder</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is more simply called <vocabulary>madder red</vocabulary>, which is a kind of <vocabulary>deep red</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crimson</vocabulary>. This word is used most often to describe the color of the sky at sunset in literature.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I went to Nishiki Market in Kyoto on Sunday.
examples.ja: 日曜日に京都の錦市場に行きました。

examples.en: These are chopsticks I bought at Nishiki Market.
examples.ja: これは錦市場で買ったお箸です。

examples.en: I bought tamago-yaki at Nishiki Market and ate it while walking around.
examples.ja: 錦市場で卵焼きを買って食べ歩きをしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You might already know 市場 means "market," like in 株式市場 (stock market). So is this a <kanji>brocade</kanji> market? Well, "brocade" actually refers to the name of a street here, not brocade fabrics. It's a place name, so we can just call this the <vocabulary>Nishiki Market</vocabulary>!

錦市場 is a famous food market on a street called 錦小路 (Nishiki Kōji) in Kyoto, and it's packed with delicious local specialties. Give it a quick search if you haven't heard of it! Maybe your next travel destination?
reading_mnemonic: As you could probably guess from the meaning, 錦 is read にしき here. 市場 is usually read with kun'yomi when it refers to a real, physical street market. You haven't learned this reading for 市場 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: There's one thing you look for when you visit Nishiki Market: an itchy baa (いちば). Sheep go "baa," and the ones you buy must be exceptionally itchy. Itchy baas produce the best mutton and wool, so you keep an eye out for them whenever you go to Nishiki Market!
